Description: Rim sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; tips of lotus flowers in added white outline with added red centres on either side of white and red rosette; exterior: at rim, band of reversed S between bands; below, painted decoration consisting of horse (part of head and mane with red remaining), to right; part of elaborate rosette as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by British School at Athens. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos describes the sherd as belonging to the Group with the Filling Ornament. The features typical for this group of vessels are the milky white slip and the use of filling ornament, which is found only in this group of sherds of the Grand Style. The presence of filling ornament also suggests that the vases were mostly likely the earliest in that style. The male figures portrayed on vases from this group are perhaps the most expertly depicted and may all have been done by the same hand. Finally, the attempt at creating some perspective is rather clumsy. For parallels regarding the horse, see British Museum 1888,0601.518, and for horses and Chian pottery, Johnston, BICS 29 (1982) 39 (pl. 5c - this vase)
The number '12' is written in ink on the exterior surface of the sherd.
